entry.name: biological entity
entry.definition: __material entity__ that was or is a living organism

entry.name: entity
entry.definition: concrete or abstract thing that exists, did exist, or might exist, including associations among these things
entry.example: A person, object, event, idea, process, etc.

entry.name: immaterial entity
entry.definition: __entity__ that does not occupy three-dimensional space\r\n
entry.example: Idea, process, organization, etc.

entry.name: material entity
entry.definition: __entity__ that occupies three-dimensional space
entry.note: All material entities have certain characteristics that can be described and therefore this concept is important for ontology purposes.

entry.name: non-biological entity
entry.definition: __material entity__ that is not and has never been a living organism

entry.name: person
entry.definition: __biological entity__ that is a natural or legal person, recognized by law as having legal rights and duties, able to make commitment(s), assume and fulfil resulting obligation(s), and able to be held accountable for its action(s)
entry.note: Minimum and common external constraints applicable to a business transaction often require one to differentiate among three common sub-types of Person, namely "individual", "organization", and "public administration".
Person is capitalized to indicate that it is being utilized as formally defined in the standards and to differentiate it from its day-to-day use.
Synonyms for "legal person" include "artificial person", "body corporate", etc., depending on the terminology used in competent jurisdictions.
entry.source: ISO/IEC 14662:2010(en), 3.24, modified to add reference to entity definition
ISO/TR 17185-1, adapted to conform to our concept model

entry.name: cooperative ITS
entry.definition: subset of __ITS__ where information is shared among __physical objects__ based on mutual security agreements with a credentialing system

entry.name: intelligent transport system
entry.definition: __technology system__ that is designed to benefit a __surface transport system__
entry.note: Benefits potentially include, but are not limited to, increased safety, sustainability, efficiency, and comfort.

The long form (i.e., "intelligent transport system") is often used when the noun is used as a subject, whereas the abbreviation (i.e., "ITS") is often used to modify another noun (e.g., "Intelligent transport systems provide ITS services.").

entry.name: surface transport system
entry.definition: __transport system__ designed to move physical entities across the surface of the earth
entry.note: A surface transport system might include tunnels, bridges, and similar elements.

entry.name: technology system
entry.definition: __system__ that is comprised of information, communication, sensor, and control technologies

entry.name: transport system
entry.definition: __system__ of infrastructure elements and optionally __vehicles__ that jointly are designed to move __entities__ from an origin to a destination
entry.note: Transport systems are not necessarily limited to the transport of physical entities; the Internet could be considered a transport system of electronic entities.

entry.name: architecture
entry.definition: <system> fundamental concepts or properties of a system in its __environment__ embodied in its __elements__, relationships, and in the principles of its design and evolution

entry.name: architecture description
entry.definition: work product used to express an __architecture__

entry.name: architecture framework
entry.definition: conventions, principles and practices for the description of __architectures__ established within a specific domain of application and/or community of stakeholders
entry.example: Generalised Enterprise Reference Architecture and Methodologies (GERAM) [ISO 15704] is an architecture framework.
Reference Model of Open Distributed Processing (RM-ODP) [ISO/IEC 10746] is an architecture framework.

entry.name: architecture model
entry.definition: work product representing one or more __architecture views__ and expressed in a format governed by a __model kind__

entry.name: architecture view
entry.definition: work product expressing the __architecture__ of a system from the perspective of specific system __concerns__

entry.name: architecture viewpoint
entry.definition: work product establishing the conventions for the construction, interpretation and use of __architecture views__ to frame specific system __concerns__

entry.name: concern
entry.definition: <system> interest in a system relevant to one or more of its __stakeholders__
entry.note: A concern pertains to any influence on a system in its environment, including developmental, technological, business, operational, organizational, political, economic, legal, regulatory, ecological and social influences.

entry.name: element
entry.definition: <architecture> component member of an __architecture model__ included in an __architecture view__

entry.name: environment
entry.definition: <system> context determining the setting and circumstances of all influences upon a system
entry.note: The environment of a system includes developmental, technological, business, operational, organizational, political, economic, legal, regulatory, ecological and social influences.

entry.name: model kind
entry.definition: conventions for a type of modelling
entry.note: Examples of model kinds include data flow diagrams, class diagrams, Petri nets, balance sheets, organization charts and state transition models.

entry.name: stakeholder
entry.definition: <system> individual, team, organization, or classes thereof, having an interest in a system

entry.name: system
entry.definition: combination of interacting elements organized to achieve one or more stated purposes

entry.name: communications view
entry.definition: __architecture view__ from the __communications viewpoint__
entry.note: Within ITS, the preferred model for describing the communications view is based on the ITS-S reference architecture.

entry.name: communications viewpoint
entry.definition: __architecture viewpoint__ used to frame communication interface concerns, including all layers of the OSI stack and related management and security issues

entry.name: enterprise view
entry.definition: __architecture view__ from the __enterprise viewpoint__

entry.name: enterprise viewpoint
entry.definition: __architecture viewpoint__ used to frame the policies, funding incentives, working arrangements, and jurisdictional structure that support the technical layers of the architecture

entry.name: functional view
entry.definition: __architecture view__ from the __functional viewpoint__

entry.name: functional viewpoint
entry.definition: __architecture viewpoint__ used to frame the functionality concerns, including the definition of processes that perform transport functions and data flows shared between these processes

entry.name: physical view
entry.definition: __architecture view__ from the __physical viewpoint__
entry.note: The term "deployment view" is sometimes used within the broader ICT community, but the term "physical view" is preferred to prevent confusion between the physical view of a reference architecture and any part of a deployment architecture.

entry.name: physical viewpoint
entry.definition: __architecture viewpoint__ used to frame system engineering concerns, including the assignment of functionality to __physical objects__ and the interfaces among these physical objects

entry.name: access layer
entry.definition: <ITS-S> part of the __data plane__ that provides the functionality related to the physical and data link layers of the open systems interconnect (OSI) reference model
entry.note: Within the IETF, the term "link layer" is used to describe the same functionality as the ITS-S reference architecture access layer.
Within the US, the NTCIP standards use the term "subnet layer" to describe the same functionality as the ITS-S reference architecture.

entry.name: application entity
entry.definition: <ITS-S> part of the __ITS station reference architecture__ that is responsible for providing ITS-related functionality

entry.name: data plane
entry.definition: <ITS-S> part of the __ITS station reference architecture__ that is responsible for handling communications with other __physical objects__

entry.name: facilities layer
entry.definition: <ITS-S> part of the __data plane__ that provides the functionality related to the session, presentation, and application layers of the open systems interconnect (OSI) reference model
entry.note: Within the US, the NTCIP standards call the facilities layer the "application layer"; however, as this term is easily confused with both the OSI application layer and the application entity, the term should be avoided.

entry.name: management entity
entry.definition: <ITS-S> part of the __ITS station reference architecture__ that is responsible for management of communications and configuration information for the local __physical object__ and possibly remote physical objects

entry.name: security entity
entry.definition: <ITS-S> part of the __ITS station reference architecture__ that is responsible for providing privacy, communication security, and system security

entry.name: transnet layer
entry.definition: <ITS-S> part of the __data plane__ that provides the functionality related to the network and transport layers of the open systems interconnect (OSI) reference model
entry.note: The full name of this layer is the networking and transport layer, but the term transnet layer provides a more concise name.

entry.name: document
entry.definition: uniquely identified unit of information for human use
entry.example: A report, specification, manual, or book, in printed or electronic form.
entry.note: A document can be a single information item, or part of a larger information item.

entry.name: enterprise object
entry.definition: __element__ within an __enterprise view__ that represents an organization or individual

entry.name: extends
entry.definition: <enterprise view> __relationship__ where one __resource__ supplements another resource
entry.example: A functional object might extend the functionality of another functional object.

entry.name: formal coordination
entry.definition: <enterprise view> __interaction__ between two __enterprise objects__ governed by a documented agreement
entry.example: A roadway operator might enter into formal agreement(s) with the owner of a roadway and the owner(s) of the associated roadway equipment.

entry.name: includes
entry.definition: <enterprise view> __relationship__ where one __resource__ contains another resource
entry.example: Every ITS component includes one or more functional objects.

entry.name: informal coordination
entry.definition: <enterprise view> __interaction__ between two __enterprise objects__ governed by an understanding that is not documented in a formal agreement between the two parties
entry.example: A pedestrian might reasonably expect that the roadway operator will provide a safe environment even though there is no direct formal agreement between the pedestrian and roadway operator.

entry.name: interaction
entry.definition: <enterprise view> __element__ that represents coordination between two __enterprise objects__

entry.name: relationship
entry.definition: <enterprise view> __element__ that represents an association between two __resources__

entry.name: resource
entry.definition: <enterprise view> __element__ that represents an entity that is related to an enterprise object

entry.name: role
entry.definition: <enterprise view> __element__ that represents the association between an __enterprise object__ and another enterprise view element
entry.example: A driver operates a vehicle.

entry.name: data flow
entry.definition: representation of data flowing between two __processes__ or between a process and a __terminator__

entry.name: process
entry.definition: <functional view> function or activity required to support an __ITS service__

entry.name: process specification
entry.definition: document that defines a lowest-level process

entry.name: functional object
entry.definition: group of similar system __processes__ from the __functional view__ of the __architecture__ that are jointly assigned to a __physical object__ in the __physical view__.
entry.example: A vehicle OBE might include a "vehicle basic safety" functional object.

entry.name: information flow
entry.definition: information that is exchanged between __physical objects__

entry.name: information transfer
entry.definition: __information flow__ from a __physical object__ acting as an information source and sent to another __physical object__ acting as an information sink

entry.name: ITS component
entry.definition: __physical object__ that has been assigned one or more ITS __functional objects__
entry.note: Physical objects are ITS components if they are an integral part of the system; otherwise they are terminators.

entry.name: physical object
entry.definition: material entity that interacts with other material entities in the provision of __ITS services__
entry.note: Physical objects are represented as elements within the physical view of an ITS architecture.
WIthin many ITS reference architectures, physical objects are placed into one of five categories: centre, support, field, vehicle, or traveller.

entry.name: terminator
entry.definition: __physical object__ that has not been assigned any ITS functional objects within the scope of the ITS service being considered
entry.note: A terminator may be a user external to ITS.

entry.name: C-ITS reference architecture
entry.definition: __reference architecture__ for one or more __ITS services__ where each service requires at least one C-ITS __information exchange__

entry.name: deployment architecture
entry.definition: __architecture__ that provides a vision of a specific deployment of a system within a geographic area

entry.name: ITS deployment architecture
entry.definition: __deployment architecture__ for one or more __ITS services__

entry.name: ITS planning architecture
entry.definition: __planning architecture__ for one or more __ITS services__

entry.name: ITS reference architecture
entry.definition: __reference architecture__ for one or more __ITS services__
entry.note: An ITS architecture might be a reference, planning, or deployment architecture.
The Harmonised Architecture Reference for Technical Standards (HARTS; http://htg7.org) is an example of an ITS reference architecture.

entry.name: ITS-S reference architecture
entry.definition: __reference architecture__ for handling communications within a __physical object__
entry.note: The ITS-S reference architecture is defined in IAO 21217.

entry.name: planning architecture
entry.definition: __architecture__ that provides a long-term vision of __system elements__ that may be deployed and managed by different projects and/or entities within a geographic area
entry.note: Some countries use the term "regional architecture", but in international standards, the term "regional" is avoided due to its multiple meanings.

entry.name: reference architecture
entry.definition: __architecture__ that provides a template solution for __planning__ and __deployment architectures__
entry.note: Interface standards are based on a reference architecture, which should be explicitly described.
entry.source: Wikipedia the free encyclopedia - definition of reference architecture [Internet]. [cited 2018 Jul 17]; Available from: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/reference_architecture

entry.name: data
entry.definition: reinterpretable representation of information in a formalized manner suitable for communication, interpretation or processing

entry.name: data concept
entry.definition: __immaterial entity__ that defines data using, at a minimum, an unambiguous identifier, a term, and a definition
entry.note: Data concepts can be classified into the following types: object class, value domain, data element, aggregate domain, data frame, message, interface dialogue, dictionary document, or module
entry.source: ISO 8000-2:2018, 3.6.1, modified to fit the ISO14812 concept model

entry.name: data concept registry
entry.definition: electronic __data dictionary__ that follows precise documented rules for the registration and management of stored __data concepts__
entry.note: A data registry typically includes advanced features for adding, retrieving, and working with its contents

entry.name: data dictionary
entry.definition: documentation of __data concepts__ and their meta-attributes in a consistent format

entry.name: meta-attribute
entry.definition: documenting characteristic of a data concept that is stored in a data dictionary

entry.name: aggregate domain
entry.definition: __data concept__ that defines a grouping of __data elements__ and/or __data frames__

entry.name: data element
entry.definition: __data concept__ represented by a specific __value domain__ and that describes a single atomic property about an __object class__.
entry.note: A data element is composed of an object class, a property of the represented object class and a value domain.

entry.name: data frame
entry.definition: __data concept__ represented by a specific __aggregate domain__ and that describes information of interest through a useful grouping of more atomic properties about one or more __object classes__.
entry.note: The grouping may be a set, sequence, or a choice.

entry.name: interface dialogue
entry.definition: __data concept__ that defines bi-directional communication sequence between two parties in accordance with predetermined protocols

entry.name: message
entry.definition: __data concept__ that is a grouping of __data elements__, __data frames__, or __data elements__ and __data frames__ that is used to convey a complete set of information

entry.name: object class
entry.definition: description of a set of objects that share the same properties, relationships, and semantics
entry.note: Adapted from ISO/IEC 11179-1:2013; an object class is conceptually similar to an ISO/IEC 11179 object, but it does not include operations or methods and ISO/IEC 11179 "attributes" are called "properties" in this International Standard.

entry.name: value domain
entry.definition: __data concept__ that defines a set of permissible values

entry.name: scenario
entry.definition: <use case> a description of the sequence of events from the user's perspective to perform a task in a specified context
entry.source: ISO/IEC 25062:2006(en), A.17, added the context of a use case

entry.name: use case
entry.definition: description of the behavioural requirements of a system and its interaction with a user

entry.name: centre system
entry.definition: __ITS component__ that provides application, management, and/or administrative functions from a centralized location (i.e., not at the __roadside__)

entry.name: field system
entry.definition: __ITS component__ that performs localized surveillance, traffic control, information provision, payment transaction, wireless communication services between mobile elements and fixed infrastructure, and/or other services.
entry.example: traffic detector, camera, signal controller, message sign, tolling station
entry.note: Typically, field systems are located along the roadside.
Typically, the operation of field systems are governed by management functions running in centre systems.

entry.name: personal system
entry.definition: __ITS component__, other than a __vehicle system__, that is used by a person in relation to a past, current, or upcoming journey

entry.name: support system
entry.definition: __ITS component__ that provides support services for one or more other ITS components

entry.name: vehicle system
entry.definition: __ITS component__ that is installed as a component of a __vehicle__

entry.name: emergency management system
entry.definition: __centre system__ that allows an entity to manage and respond to crashes, events, disasters, evacuation orders, and other incidents

entry.name: fleet and freight management system
entry.definition: __centre system__ that allows a fleet or freight operator to manage and control its personnel, equipment, and/or freight

entry.name: maintenance and construction management system
entry.definition: __centre system__ that allows an entity to monitor and manage the construction and maintenance of roadway infrastructure

entry.name: payment administration system
entry.definition: __centre system__ that allows an entity to manage financial transactions related to transportation, especially the electronic transfer of funds

entry.name: public transport system
entry.definition: __centre system__ that allows an entity to manage the activities of a public transport agency

entry.name: traffic management system
entry.definition: __centre system__ that monitors and controls traffic and the road network

entry.name: traffic regulatory system
entry.definition: __centre system__ that officially records traffic regulations in electronic form so that they can be distributed to other systems

entry.name: transport information system
entry.definition: __centre system__ that provides information of interest to the travelling public

entry.name: field support equipment
entry.definition: portable __field system__ used by field personnel to locally troubleshoot, initialize, reprogram, and test infrastructure equipment

entry.name: ITS roadway equipment
entry.definition: __field system__ that performs localized surveillance, traffic control, information provision, and/or payment transaction services

entry.name: roadside equipment
entry.definition: __field system__ used to send electronic messages to and receive messages from nearby __vehicle systems__ and __traveller systems__ via wireless technologies

entry.name: roadside unit
entry.definition: component of __roadside equipment__ that performs the logical control functions

entry.name: external in-vehicle device
entry.definition: __personal system____ consisting of GNSS and/or cellular modules that are connected to a vehicle during a trip__

entry.name: nomadic device
entry.definition: __personal information device__ that is taken with and can be accessed by the traveller during a journey

entry.name: personal information device
entry.definition: __personal system__ that enables personal access to traveller information
entry.example: personal computer

entry.name: public information device
entry.definition: __personal system__ that provides public access to traveller information
entry.example: kiosk

entry.name: cooperative ITS credentials management system
entry.definition: __support system__ that enables trusted communications among ITS components and protects data from unauthorized access

entry.name: map update system
entry.definition: __support system__ that provides map databases used to support __ITS services__

entry.name: commercial vehicle OBE
entry.definition: __vehicle OBE__ that provides functionality related to commercial vehicle operations

entry.name: emergency vehicle OBE
entry.definition: __vehicle OBE__ that provides functionality related to emergency vehicle operations

entry.name: public transport vehicle OBE
entry.definition: __vehicle OBE__ that provides functionality related to public transport vehicle operations

entry.name: vehicle onboard equipment
entry.definition: __vehicle system__ that provides the onboard functions necessary to support the ITS services supported by the vehicle
entry.note: It is preferred to include the word "vehicle" in the term so that it is sufficiently well distinguished from the specialized types of OBEs.
The vehicle onboard equipment may also perform other functions.

entry.name: vehicle onboard unit
entry.definition: component of __vehicle onboard equipment__ that performs the logical control functions

entry.name: ITS station
entry.definition: portion of an __ITS component__ that provides a __bounded secured managed domain__ and conforms to the __ITS-S reference architecture__
entry.note: The ITS station architecture is defined in ISO 21217.

entry.name: ITS-S unit
entry.definition: instantiation of an __ITS station__

entry.name: application template
entry.definition: <ITS> executable technical pattern of an __ITS application specification__

entry.name: interoperability design
entry.definition: characteristics necessary to fully define how various __physical objects__ interoperate to provide a __service__
entry.note: Characteristics often include but are not limited to functional, performance, and interface requirements.

entry.name: ITS application
entry.definition: __interoperability design__ for an __ITS service__
entry.note: The interoperability design does not have to be publicly available; it may be a proprietary design.

The interoperability design for an ITS application identifies how the different ITS application roles inter-relate. In the simplest case, there might be a single role that interoperates with other instances of the same role type.

entry.name: ITS application specification
entry.definition: one or more documents that detail all necessary requirements for an __ITS application__

entry.name: ITS deployment
entry.definition: installation capable of implementing one or more __ITS applications__
entry.note: An ITS deployment typically refers to the support, central and roadside ITS stations coupled with a tacit acknowledgement of the mobile ITS stations that will communicate with the support, central, or roadside ITS stations.

entry.name: ITS implementation
entry.definition: integration of each __physical object__ necessary to implement one or more __ITS applications__
entry.note: An ITS implementation is typically used for a laboratory or other experimental environment prior to a full-scale deployment.

entry.name: ITS application role
entry.definition: __ITS-S user need__ expressed as a formal set of interoperability requirements that need to be fulfilled to satisfy a portion of functionality of an __ITS application__

entry.name: ITS-S application
entry.definition: __ITS-S application process__ residing in the __application entity__

entry.name: ITS-S application implementation
entry.definition: __ITS-S application process implementation__ within the __application entity__

entry.name: ITS-S application installation
entry.definition: __ITS-S application process installation__ within the __application entity__

entry.name: ITS-S application instance
entry.definition: __ITS-S application process instance__ within the __application entity__

entry.name: ITS-S application process
entry.definition: element in an __ITS station__ that performs information processing for an __ITS-S service__

entry.name: ITS-S application process implementation
entry.definition: implementation of an __ITS-S application process__
entry.note: A unique implementation is typically associated with an implementation name, a version, and release number.

entry.name: ITS-S application process installation
entry.definition: installation of an __ITS-S application process implementation__
entry.note: A unique installation is typically associated with a specific license code or serial number.

entry.name: ITS-S application process instance
entry.definition: run-time instance of an __ITS-S application process installation__

entry.name: carriageway
entry.definition: contiguous width of __roadway__
entry.note: A carriageway is comprised of one or more travel lanes (i.e., the travelled way) and may include shoulders and lay-bys.
When looking at a cross-section of the right-of-way, the roadway consists of all of the carriageways and carriageways are separated by physical barriers.

entry.name: cycle lane
entry.definition: __lane__ designed for the through movement of human-powered __vehicles__
entry.note: Cycle lanes are typically much narrower than travel lanes.
Cycle lanes may also allow and be designed for motorized vehicles (e.g., e-scooters, mopeds, etc.) with similar performance characteristics as human-powered cycles, subject to local regulations.

entry.name: dual carriageway
entry.definition: __roadway__ comprised of exactly two __carriageways__
entry.note: The two carriageways are typically designed for travel in opposite directions.

entry.name: easement
entry.definition: stretch of land reserved for transportation purposes
entry.note: The easement includes all carriageways as well as a significant width to allow for roadside devices, clearance zones, sidewalks, drainage facilities, sound walls, etc.
This concept is sometimes referred to as "right-of-way"; however, the preferred meaning of "right-of-way" is to identify which vehicle has the legal authority to access a portion of roadway.

entry.name: footway
entry.definition: __lane__ designed for the through movement of pedestrians
entry.note: Other modes of transport may also use footways, subject to local regulations.

entry.name: lane
entry.definition: portion of __easement __intended for a specific purpose along its length with adequate clearance for its purpose
entry.example: shoulder
entry.note: Lanes are often bounded by lane markings.
Lanes may be significantly wider than the normal vehicle width to allow variance in lane position of the vehicle as well as for various vehicle dimensions.
The "lane" nomenclature typically refers to motor vehicle usage, but can also refer to other purposes, such as sidewalks.

entry.name: lay-by
entry.definition: short __lane__ at the edge of a __carriageway__ designed to allow a __motor vehicle__ to temporarily stop while traffic in other __lanes__ proceed
entry.note: Lay-bys might be used for emergency situations, picking up/dropping off passengers, etc.

entry.name: multi-carriageway
entry.definition: __roadway__ comprised of more than two __carriageways__
entry.note: The separate carriageways are typically designed for separate traffic for (often multiple) specific operational reasons, such as direction of travel, category of vehicle (e.g., high occupancy vehicle), local versus through travel, etc.

entry.name: reserved lane
entry.definition: __travel lane__ restricted to a specific subset of __motor vehicles__
entry.example: Bus lane
High-occupancy vehicle lane

entry.name: roadside
entry.definition: portion between one edge of the __easement__ and the closest edge of a __carriageway__

entry.name: roadway
entry.definition: part of the __easement__ designed for use by __motor vehicles__
entry.note: Roadway relates to a cross-section of a road facility (i.e., zero length). See "road", "road section", "road segment", and "road link" for different types of stretches of roadway.

entry.name: separation barrier
entry.definition: barrier that separates __carriageways__

entry.name: shoulder
entry.definition: __lane__ between the edge of a __carriageway__ and any slope or edge of __right-of-way__
entry.note: The shoulder might be used for emergency stops or other purposes in addition to providing a clear zone and to promote ground stability at the edge of the carriageway.

entry.name: single carriageway
entry.definition: __roadway__ comprised of exactly one __carriageway__

entry.name: travel lane
entry.definition: __lane__ designed for the through movement of __motor vehicles__

entry.name: traveled way
entry.definition: collection of all travel lanes of a carriageway

entry.name: lane link
entry.definition: __lane__ with starting and ending points that correspond to the starting and ending points of a __road link__

entry.name: lane section
entry.definition: complete sequential series of __lane segments__ within a __road section__

entry.name: lane segment
entry.definition: complete sequential series of __lane links__ within a __road segment__
entry.note: A lane segment might start or end at locations other than the start or end of the corresponding road segment (e.g., a lane may start mid-block).
A lane segment only includes the sequential lane links, it does not include lane links from adjacent lanes.

entry.name: path link
entry.definition: collection of all __lane links__ of the same __road link__ and __carriageway__ designed for travel in the same direction

entry.name: road
entry.definition: contiguous curvilinear length of the __road network__ that shares the same name
entry.note: A length of the road network may be referenced by multiple names (e.g., Main Street and Route 7). In this case, there would be two "roads" that share the same set of "carriageways".
A road may turn at a junction.

entry.name: road link
entry.definition: contiguous length of a __road segment__ that is described by the same set of physical characteristics

entry.name: road network
entry.definition: interconnected collection of non-rail routes designed for the movement of motorized, land-based, wheeled vehicles up to 2.5 metres in width
entry.note: Other vehicles might be allowed to use the road network, perhaps with additional regulations, but the roads are designed based on these characteristics.
Portions of the road network might impose additional restrictions through the use of signs or other notices.

entry.name: road section
entry.definition: contiguous length of a __road__ that shares the same management and operational characteristics
entry.example: A traffic signal timing plan is applied to one road section.

entry.name: road segment
entry.definition: contiguous length of a __road section__ bounded by a __junction__, a jurisdictional boundary, a road section boundary, or a termination point at both ends

entry.name: egress lane
entry.definition: __travel lane__ designed for exiting from a __junction__

entry.name: egress link
entry.definition: __directional lanes link__ representing all __egress lanes__ on a __road link__

entry.name: ingress lane
entry.definition: __travel lane__ designed for entry into a __junction__

entry.name: ingress link
entry.definition: __directional lanes link__ representing all __ingress lanes__ on a __road link__

entry.name: interchange
entry.definition: __junction__ where at least one movement is grade separated from all other movements
entry.example: A diamond interchange has two intersections.
entry.note: The concept of an interchange includes all movements at the junction, which may include multiple intersections.
The grade separation allows travelers on the link to pass unimpeded through the junction when congestion is not present.

entry.name: intersection
entry.definition: at-grade __junction__, or a portion thereof, that is operated as a single entity

entry.name: junction
entry.definition: nexus where two or more roads meet in a manner that allows travellers to change roads
entry.note: While the nexus is sometimes modelled as a point, it does in fact consume space

entry.name: maneuver
entry.definition: movement from an __ingress lane__ to an __egress lane__

entry.name: area location
entry.definition: __location__ that has a two-dimensional character

entry.name: linear location
entry.definition: location that has a one-dimensional character

entry.name: location
entry.definition: identifiable place within a three-dimensional space
entry.note: Within ITS, locations are typically locations on or near the surface of the earth.

entry.name: point location
entry.definition: location that has a zero-dimensional character

entry.name: dynamic location reference
entry.definition: location reference generated on-the-fly based on geographic properties in a digital map database

entry.name: link location
entry.definition: pre-coded location reference defined within the road network database

entry.name: location code
entry.definition: identifier assigned to a location reference
entry.note: A location code is often a numeric or alphanumeric identifier, but could be a textual name, symbol, or any other type of identifier.

entry.name: location reference
entry.definition: specification of a location according to a specific set of rules

entry.name: location referencing
entry.definition: method for referencing locations to facilitate the exchange of location related information between different systems

entry.name: location table
entry.definition: table of one or more entries that unambiguously defines a location according to a known set of conventions

entry.name: pre-coded location reference
entry.definition: location reference using a unique identifier that is agreed upon in both sender and receiver system to select a location from a set of pre-coded locations

entry.name: service
entry.definition: performance of one or more tasks or provision of one or more facilities to enable one or more tasks to fulfil a __need__ for a __user__

entry.name: service provider
entry.definition: __entity__ that delivers one or more __services__

entry.name: user
entry.definition: __entity__ that has a __need__ to be fulfilled

entry.name: user need
entry.definition: factor or condition necessary to achieve desired results within a specified context of use

entry.name: consumer
entry.definition: <transport> __consumer__ that has a __transport need__ to be fulfilled

entry.name: item
entry.definition: <transport> __material entity__ that has been, is being, or will be transported

entry.name: need
entry.definition: <transport> __need__ to transport one or more transport items to a different location

entry.name: provider
entry.definition: <transport> __entity__ that delivers one or more __transport services__

entry.name: service
entry.definition: <transport> __service__ that delivers item(s) from one location to another on behalf of a __transport consumer__ to satisfy a __need__
entry.note: The item(s) delivered might be people and/or goods.

entry.name: service
entry.definition: <ITS> performance of one or more tasks to fulfil an __ITS user need__ for an __ITS user__

entry.name: service provider
entry.definition: <ITS> __entity__ that delivers one or more __ITS services__

entry.name: user
entry.definition: <ITS> __entity__ that has an __ITS user need__ to be fulfilled

entry.name: user need
entry.definition: <ITS> __need__ of an entity external to the intelligent transport system for a __surface transport system__ benefit that can be met with the use of a __technology system__
entry.example: Increasing safety, sustainability, efficiency, and/or comfort

entry.name: bounded, secured, managed domain
entry.definition: controlled processing environment that adheres to a minimum set of management and security principles and procedures so as to establish a level of trust between itself and other similar __ITS stations__ with which it might communicate

entry.name: service
entry.definition: <ITS-S> performance of one or more tasks to fulfil an __ITS-S user need__ for an __ITS-S user__

entry.name: service provider
entry.definition: <ITS-S> __ITS-S__ that delivers one or more __ITS-S services__

entry.name: user
entry.definition: <ITS-S> __entity__ that has an __ITS-S user need__ to be fulfilled

entry.name: user need
entry.definition: <ITS-S> __need__ for processing within a __bounded, secure, managed domain__

entry.name: communication need
entry.definition: <ITS-S> __need__ for communication functionality that connects an __ITS-S__ to other nodes

entry.name: communication process
entry.definition: <ITS-S> __entity__ that delivers one or more __ITS-S communication services__

entry.name: communication service
entry.definition: <ITS-S> performance of one or more tasks to fulfil an __ITS-S communication need__ for an __ITS-S communication user__

entry.name: communication user
entry.definition: <ITS-S> __entity__ that has an __ITS-S communication need__ to be fulfilled

entry.name: AV sharing
entry.definition: using a __shared AV service__

entry.name: shared AV service
entry.definition: __shared mobility service__ where the on-board logic within the vehicle has the primary responsibility for the operation of the __vehicle__

entry.name: shared mobility service
entry.definition: __transport service__ delivered by a __transport provider__ that uses the same equipment and/or staff to provide transport services to multiple unrelated __transport consumers__
entry.note: A shared mobility service can be characterized by its contractual, financial, network, and operational models.

entry.name: shared transport service
entry.definition: __shared mobility service__ where the __transport provider__ has the primary responsibility for the selection and operation of the transport mode
entry.note: A shared transport system might not be dependent upon a vehicle and/or could be multi-modal. For example, a letter courier service could rely on walking and public transport.

Responsibilities of the transport service might be further delegated to others. For example, a courier service relying on public transport would delegate the operation of the transport mode to the public transport operator.

entry.name: shared vehicle service
entry.definition: __shared mobility service__ where the __transport consumer__ has the primary responsibility for the operation of the __vehicle__
entry.note: As there should only be one operator of a vehicle at any time, a shared vehicle service should use a sequential operational model.

This term can be specialized by replacing "vehicle" with any defined vehicle type; however, in some cases the the preferred form is to consolidate terms (e.g., "carsharing" rather than "passenger car sharing").

entry.name: transport sharing
entry.definition: using a __shared transport service__

entry.name: vehicle sharing
entry.definition: using a __shared vehicle service__

entry.name: business-to-business
entry.definition: <shared mobility> __contractual model__ where the __transport provider__ is a commercial entity or governmental agency and the __transport consumer__ is a commercial entity
entry.example: A business purchasing monthly public transport passes for its employees
A commercial entity using a commercial courier service for package delivery

entry.name: business-to-consumer
entry.definition: <shared mobility> __contractual model__ where the __transport provider__ is a commercial entity or governmental agency and the __transport consumer__ is an individual

entry.name: business-to-government
entry.definition: <shared mobility> __contractual model__ where the __transport provider__ is a commercial entity or governmental agency and the __transport consumer__ is a governmental entity
entry.example: A governmental entity using a commercial courier service for package delivery

entry.name: contractual model
entry.definition: <shared mobility> legal framework used by a __shared mobility service__
entry.note: Contracts might be via a third party, implied or verbal, especially in the case of peer-to-peer.

entry.name: peer-to-peer
entry.definition: <shared mobility> __contractual model__ where both the __transport provider__ and the __transport consumer__ are individuals
entry.example: ridesourcing
entry.note: The two individuals may connect and/or contract through a thrid party service.

entry.name: commercial
entry.definition: <shared mobility> __financial model__ where __transport services__ are provided with a profit motive

entry.name: cooperative
entry.definition: <shared mobility> __financial model__ where __transport consumers__ partner to defray the costs of __transport services__
entry.note: Cooperative models are exclusive commercial and public models.

entry.name: financial model
entry.definition: <shared mobility> economic framework used by a __shared mobility service__

entry.name: fractional ownership
entry.definition: <shared mobility> __cooperative__ financial model where __transport consumers__ partner to support the purchase, maintenance, and overhead costs associated with a vehicle

entry.name: membership modifier
entry.definition: <shared mobility> characteristic of a __financial model__ that indicates whether __transport consumers__ are required to enter into a agreement prior to receiving __transport services__

entry.name: membership-based
entry.definition: <shared mobility> characteristic of a __financial model__ that requires __transport consumers__ to enter into a agreement prior to receiving __transport services__
entry.note: The agreement might be associated with fees.
The agreement might be minimal, such as collecting user information for business purposes.
The membership may be granted as a part of a broader agreement. For example, a university bus system might restrict access to students and faculty.

entry.name: mutual benefit
entry.definition: <shared mobility> __cooperative__ financial model where __transport consumers__ partner on a per-trip basis

entry.name: open-access
entry.definition: <shared mobility> characteristic of a __financial model__ that does not require membership within an organization to receive __transport services__
entry.note: This includes models where membership is optional and might provide extra benefits.

entry.name: private
entry.definition: <shared mobility> __financial model__ where __transport services__ are provided to members of the owning organization without usage fees
entry.example: Fleet vehicles of an employer

entry.name: public
entry.definition: <shared mobility> __financial model__ where __transport services__ are provided by an administrative authority in an attempt to better serve societal interests
entry.note: The transport service is typically offered to the transport consumer for less than the full capital and operating cost of providing the service, but this is not a requirement.

Typically, the administrative authority is a local government agency; but it could be another administrative authority, such as the national government or a commercial entity managing transport needs on their campus.

entry.name: concurrent
entry.definition: <shared transport> __operational model__ where __transport services__ might be provided to multiple __transport consumers__ at any one time

entry.name: dynamic route
entry.definition: <shared transport> __concurrent__ operation where __transported items__ can only be received or delivered at stopping points within a pre-defined service corridor
entry.example: Airport shuttle
entry.note: The service corridor is defined by the provider, who may impose further restrictions on where stops are allowed.
The service corridor often includes a communal point of interest (e.g., an airport, transit hub, etc) as a fixed stopping point.

entry.name: fixed route
entry.definition: <shared transport> __concurrent__ operation where __transported items__ can only be received or delivered at stopping points contained in a pre-defined sequence
entry.example: Traditional fixed-route bus line

entry.name: operational model
entry.definition: <shared transport> logistical framework used by a __shared mobility service__
entry.note: The logistical framework might set restrictions on how a passenger and/or good is received, transported, and/or delivered.

entry.name: paired on-demand
entry.definition: <shared transport> __concurrent__ operation where the __transport provider__ may choose to divert from its path to service a new request from another __transport consumer__ while servicing an earlier transport consumer
entry.example: ridesplitting

entry.name: sequential
entry.definition: <shared transport> __operational model__ where __transport services__ are provided to a single transport consumer at any one time
entry.example: traditional taxi service
entry.note: A single transport consumer might request the transport of multiple passengers.

entry.name: free-floating one-way
entry.definition: <shared mobility> __network model__ where sharing may be initiated and terminated at any location meeting basic criteria
entry.note: The basic criteria typically include geographic limits and requirements related to legal and safe locations.

entry.name: network model
entry.definition: <shared vehicle> infrastructure framework used by a __shared mobility service__

entry.name: station-based one-way
entry.definition: <shared vehicle> __operational mode__ where __vehicle sharing__ is initiated and terminated at two different facilities managed by the __transport provider__

entry.name: station-based roundtrip
entry.definition: <shared vehicle> __operational mode__ where __vehicle sharing__ is initiated and terminated at the same facility managed by the __transport provider__

entry.name: carpool service
entry.definition: __rideshare service__ that uses a __passenger car__ for transport

entry.name: courier network service
entry.definition: __commercial__, __peer-to-peer__ __shared transport service__ that transports goods
entry.note: The goods are typically small packages, letters, food, etc.

entry.name: pedicab sevice
entry.definition: __taxi service__ that uses a __pedicycle__ to provide transport

entry.name: rideshare service
entry.definition: __cooperative__ __shared transport service__ that transports passengers __concurrently__

entry.name: ridesourced service
entry.definition: __commercial__, __peer-to-peer__ __shared transport service__ that transports passengers

entry.name: ridesplit service
entry.definition: __ridesourced service__ that serves passengers __concurrently__

entry.name: shuttle service
entry.definition: __shared transport service__ that transports passengers between two specified __locations__
entry.note: Each location might be defined as point, linear, or area locations; however, the areas of the two locations should not overlap.

entry.name: taxi service
entry.definition: __commercial__ __shared transport service__ that transports passengers __sequentially__

entry.name: taxi share service
entry.definition: __commercial__ __shared transport service__ that transports passengers __concurrently__

entry.name: vanpool service
entry.definition: __rideshare service__ that uses a __passenger van__ for transport

entry.name: bikesharing service
entry.definition: __shared vehicle service__ that shares bicycles

entry.name: carsharing service
entry.definition: __shared vehicle service__ that shares passenger cars

entry.name: B2C mobility sharing app
entry.definition: __mobility app__ that assists a __transport consumer__ in acquiring __shared mobility services__ from a specific business

entry.name: mobility app
entry.definition: __ITS-S application implementation__ designed to assist an individual transport consumer in understanding transport-related information, making decisions, and/or acting upon decisions

entry.name: mobility fitness app
entry.definition: __mobility app__ that tracks information about a traveller to provide health-related information
entry.note: The information collected may include details such as speed, elapsed travel time, heart rate, etc.
The provided health information might include caloric consumption, peak heart rate, distance travelled, etc.

entry.name: navigation app
entry.definition: __mobility app__ that assists a __transport consumer__ to determine the best route to the destination

entry.name: P2P mobility sharing app
entry.definition: __mobility app__ that assists a __transport consumer__ in acquiring __shared mobility services__ from an individual that participates in the mobility app's network

entry.name: public transport app
entry.definition: __mobility app__ that assists a __transport consumer__ in using a public transport system
entry.note: A public tranport app might include features such as viewing maps, searching routes and schedules, real-time arrival information, ticketing, electronic boarding pass, etc.

entry.name: real-time traveller information app
entry.definition: __mobility app__ that provides information about current travel conditions to a __transport consumer__

entry.name: ridesourcing app
entry.definition: __P2P mobility sharing app__ for acquiring a __ridesourced service__

entry.name: taxi hailing app
entry.definition: __mobility app__ that assists a __transport consumer__ in electronically requesting a taxi

entry.name: trip aggregator app
entry.definition: __mobility app__ that assists a __transport consumer__ in planning trips that may span multiple vehicle modes or transport providers
entry.note: The assistance might include reservations, ticketing, and similar services.

entry.name: pedestrian
entry.definition: __person__ who is travelling on foot

entry.name: road user
entry.definition: mobile __entity__ within the __easement__ of a __road__
entry.example: pedestrians, road work personnel, vehicle occupants, occupied and unoccupied vehicles, horses, etc.

entry.name: traveller
entry.definition: __person__, in the role of a __transport item__, who is headed to a destination

entry.name: vulnerable road user
entry.definition: __road user__ other than an occupant of a __motor vehicle__

entry.name: conventional driver
entry.definition: __person__ performing the role of the __driver__ using the vehicle's __built-in input devices__ to control the longitudinal and lateral movement of the vehicle

entry.name: driver
entry.definition: role that represents the __entity__ that is currently responsible for the __dynamic driving task__ for the __vehicle__
entry.note: The driver is typically onboard the vehicle, but could be remote from the vehicle or automated logic.

entry.name: passenger
entry.definition: __person__ who has a reservation to travel or is travelling in a __vehicle__ except for any crew, staff, or drivers

entry.name: remote driver
entry.definition: __person__ performing the role of the __driver__ without using the vehicle's __built-in input devices__ to control the longitudinal and lateral movement of the vehicle
entry.note: A remote driver may use a variety of physical input devces, but not any that are built into the vehicle.

entry.name: vehicle occupant
entry.definition: __person__ in a __vehicle__
entry.note: A vehicle occupant in a stationary vehicle is not necessarily a traveller.

entry.name: built-in input device
entry.definition: __input device__ designed to be physically connected to a __vehicle__ and to remain connected even when the vehicle is not in use
entry.note: Built-in input devices include devices that might be temporarily disconnected for security reasons (e.g., some radios are equipped with detachable front panels).

entry.name: input device
entry.definition: <vehicle> __material entity__ that can affect the vehicle's operation
entry.example: steering wheel, lever, pedal, knob, button, touch screen
entry.note: Input devices include those used to control the motion of the vehicle (e.g., a brake pedal), the state of vehicular equipment (e.g., headlight control), the configuration of the vehicle (e.g., temperature control), etc.

entry.name: motor
entry.definition: __material entity__ that converts energy into mechanical motion

entry.name: nomadic input device
entry.definition: __input device__ designed to be carried into, or in near proximity of, a __vehicle__ and connected as desired \r\n
entry.example: A smartphone connected to a vehicle (via USB or Bluetooth) to control the vehicle's audio system
entry.note: Nomadic devices are often more closely associated with a person than they are with the vehicle.

entry.name: remote input device
entry.definition: __input device__ designed to be electronically connected to a __vehicle__ even when the vehicle is not in close proximity

entry.name: vehicle
entry.definition: __material entity____ used to transport people or physical goods__

entry.name: wheel
entry.definition: circular __material entity__ that rotates about an axle to facilitate movement of the vehicle

entry.name: design speed
entry.definition: maximum speed at which a vehicle is intended to operate for a sustained period of time

entry.name: ADS
entry.definition: __driving automation system__ that is able to perform the entire __DDT__ on a sustained basis
entry.note: The abbreviated form (ADS") is preferred and the alternate form uses initial capitals to avoid confusion with the more general term driving automation system.

entry.name: ADS-dedicated vehicle
entry.definition: __ADS-equipped vehicle__ designed for only driverless operation for complete trips

entry.name: ADS-equipped vehicle
entry.definition: __vehicle__ integrated with an __ADS__
entry.note: This term only describes the capabilities of the vehicle, not its operational state. In other words, the term applies as long as the ADS is connected to the vehicle, whether the DDT is actively engaged or not.

entry.name: conventional vehicle
entry.definition: <driving automation> __vehicle__ designed to be operated by a __person__ during part or all of every trip.

entry.name: driver assistance
entry.definition: __driving automation system__ that provides either sustained lateral or sustained longitudinal vehicle motion control within a specific __operational design domain__ with the expectation that a __conventional driver__ completes the dynamic driving task

entry.name: driving automation system
entry.definition: hardware and software __system__ that is able to perform part or all of the __DDT__ on a sustained basis
entry.note: This term is used generically to describe any system capable of level 1-5 driving automation.

entry.name: dual-mode vehicle
entry.definition: <driving automation> __ADS-equipped vehicle__ designed for both driverless operation and operation by a __conventional driver__ for complete trips

entry.name: dynamic driving task
entry.definition: all real-time operational and tactical functions required to operate a __vehicle__ in on-road traffic
entry.note: The DDT excludes strategic functions such as trip scheduling and selection of destinations and waypoints.

entry.name: fallback
entry.definition: <driving automation> response by an __ADS__ to achieve a minimal risk condition upon exit from the defined __operational design domain__ or in response to a __system failure__

entry.name: fallback-ready user
entry.definition: <DDT> human __driver__ who is able to operate the vehicle if the __ADS__ issues a request to intervene or if the human driver otherwise identifies a condition that requires intervention to perform the __DDT__

entry.name: level 3 ADS
entry.definition: __ADS__ designed with the expectation that the __fallback-ready user__ is available to intervene
entry.note: Level 3 ADSs are typically restricted to operating within a specific ODD.
The user might need to intervene due to an ADS-issued request, a DDT performance-relevant system failure, or other reasons.

entry.name: level 4 ADS
entry.definition: __ADS__ that is capable of operating within a specific __ODD__ and providing its own __fallback__, without any expectation that a human __driver__ will respond to a request to intervene

entry.name: level 5 ADS
entry.definition: __ADS__ that is capable of unconditional (i.e., not __ODD__-specific) operation and providing its own __fallback__, without any expectation that a human __driver__ will respond to a request to intervene

entry.name: operational design domain
entry.definition: set of operating conditions under which a given __driving automation system__ or feature thereof is specifically designed to function
entry.example: An ADS feature is designed to operate a vehicle only on fully access-controlled freeways in low-speed traffic, under fair weather conditions and optimal road maintenance conditions (e.g., good lane markings and not under construction).
An ADS-dedicated vehicle is designed to operate only within a geographically-defined military base, and only during daylight at speeds not to exceed 25 mph.
entry.note: The conditions might include environmental, geographical, time-of-day, and/or other restrictions.
The conditions might require the presence or absence of certain traffic or roadway characteristics.

entry.name: partial driving automation
entry.definition: __driving automation system__ that provides sustained lateral and longitudinal vehicle motion control within a specific __operational design domain__ with the expectation that a __conventional driver__ completes the object and event detection and response

entry.name: system failure
entry.definition: <driving automation> malfunction in a vehicle system that prevents the __driving automation system__ from reliably performing its responsibilities on a sustained basis
entry.note: The malfunction may be internal to the driving automation system or part of another vehicle system.

entry.name: connected vehicle
entry.definition: __vehicle____ that is equipped with ____vehicle onboard equipment__ that is active and operational
entry.note: The equipment is active when the basic vehicle safety application processes are running.
The term connected vehicle does not imply support for any specific communications interface or ITS-S application process.

entry.name: disconnected vehicle
entry.definition: __off-grid vehicle____ that is or was equipped with ____vehicle onboard equipment__ that is sufficiently physically disconnected such that the vehicle no longer sends or receives any connected vehicle communications
entry.note: The vehicle on-board equipment might still be present in the vehicle and might even be partially connected, but not in any operational sense.

entry.name: off-grid vehicle
entry.definition: __vehicle____ that is currently unable to __send or receive any connected vehicle communications

entry.name: unconnected vehicle
entry.definition: __off-grid vehicle____ that is equipped with ____vehicle onboard equipment__ that is not active or is otherwise unable to send or receive any connected vehicle communications\r\n
entry.note: The equipment may be off or disconnected resulting in a condition where the vehicle appears to be off-grid.

entry.name: unequipped vehicle
entry.definition: __off-grid vehicle____ that is not and has never been equipped with ____vehicle onboard equipment__

entry.name: cycle-speed vehicle
entry.definition: __vehicle__ with a maximum design speed that exceeds pedestrian speeds but does not greatly exceed those for human-powered cycles
entry.note: Local regulations vary but but conceptually, this represents a maximum design speed of roughly 25 kph.

entry.name: high-speed vehicle
entry.definition: __vehicle__ with a maximum design speed that greatly exceeds motorway speeds\r\n
entry.note: Local regulations vary but but conceptually, this represents a maximum design speed in excess of 200 kph.

entry.name: motorway-speed vehicle
entry.definition: __vehicle__ with a maximum design speed that exceeds urban speeds but does not greatly exceed those for motorways
entry.note: Local regulations vary but but conceptually, this represents a maximum design speed of roughly 200 kph.

entry.name: pedestrian-speed vehicle
entry.definition: __vehicle__ with a maximum design speed that does not greatly exceed typical pedestrian speeds
entry.note: Local regulations vary but but conceptually, this represents a maximum design speed of roughly 5 kph.

entry.name: residential-speed vehicle
entry.definition: __vehicle__ with a maximum design speed that exceeds cycle speeds but does not greatly exceed those considered safe for residential neighbourhoods
entry.note: Local regulations vary but but conceptually, this represents a maximum design speed of roughly 50 kph.

entry.name: urban-speed vehicle
entry.definition: __vehicle__ with a maximum design speed that exceeds residential speeds but does not greatly exceed those considered safe for all urban roads not meeting motorway standards
entry.note: Local regulations vary but but conceptually, this represents a maximum design speed of roughly 100 kph.
